author: Chris Leadbeater
title: The 5 best family days out from Birmingham
text: Follow the links below to see the rest of our guide • The best family days out from Manchester • The best family days out from Bristol • The best family days out from Newcastle • The best family days out from London Sutton Park Six miles north of central Birmingham in Sutton Coldfield, Sutton Park is so vast (2,400 acres) that it ranks as the seventh largest urban park in Europe. It offers a happy mix of lakes (seven in all), woodland and trails, plus restaurants and two children’s playgrounds. Its crowning glory, however, may be the donkey sanctuary, where junior visitors can meet, pet and even adopt these gentle animals. birmingham.gov.uk/suttonpark ; 0121 3549444; thedonkeysanctuary.co.uk ; free. • 50 great days out in the UK • Holiday complaints: what to do when things go wrong • How to survive a long car journey with children Warwick Castle Flit 30 miles south east of Birmingham, to Warwick, and you find one of Britain’s finest examples of medieval architecture. Founded in the 11th century and expanded in the 14th, Warwick Castle has a magical maze for junior knights and damsels, who can run down their batteries by running up its still-grand fortifications (the 45m Caesar’s Tower or the 39m Guy’s Tower), before enjoying a more sedentary Horrible Histories stage show. 0871 265 2000; warwick-castle.com ; adult £18.45, child (4-11) £16.20, under-fours free, family of four from £53.55. Warwick is one of Britain’s finest examples of medieval architecture Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Charlecote Park A 16th-century manor house framed by a lovely country estate, 35 miles south of the city at Wellesbourne, in Warwickshire, Charlecote Park is playing an enthusiastic part in the National Trust’s 50 things to do before you’re 11¾ programme. Eleven of these rewardingly tiring suggestions can be tackled in the grounds, including deer-tracking, kite-flying, conkers, hunting for bugs in grass and catching falling leaves. 01789 470 277; nationaltrust.org.uk/charlecote-park ; adult £10.05, child £5, family from £25. • The 20 best hidden beaches in the UK • How to survive a family trip to the zoo • Flying with children: 10 secrets to stress-free travel Ackers Adventure A giant multifaceted playground four miles south east of the centre in Sparkbrook, Ackers Adventure calls to energetic youngsters with a feast of options likely to help them expend all their summer energy, from kayaking and climbing walls to zipwires and a tower jump where daredevils drop 20m in a safety harness. Prices vary according to the activity, but lessons for children aged from four to seven on the centre’s dry ski slope start at £19.50. 0121 772 5111; ackers-adventure.co.uk . There are a couple of watersports options close to the city Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Nene Whitewater Centre Water babies will be drawn to Nene Whitewater Centre, 50 miles to the south east in Northampton, and easily reached via the M6 and M1. This artificial rafting and tubing course provides splash-happy afternoons in controlled conditions. Its Kids Activity Days, which run until the end of August, are aimed at children aged from seven to 17. Two-day sessions, which feature kayaking as well as rafting, cost £75 a head. 01604 634 040; nenewhitewatercentre.co.uk Follow @telegraphtravel
